Idiom (Limonese Creole): Monkey know which tree fi climb
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: People know who they can take advantage of or where they can act safely.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: People act differently depending on who they deal with.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Caribbean proverb linked to observation of monkey behavior—common in plantation folklore.
First Example Sentence: Yu si how him quiet roun di boss? Monkey know which tree fi climb.
Second Example Sentence: She neva answer di teacher back—monkey know which tree fi climb.
Third Example Sentence: Mi tell yu, dem smart—monkey know which tree fi climb fi true.

Idiom (Limonese Creole): One one coco full di basket
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Small efforts or contributions eventually add up to something big.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rooted in rural Caribbean culture emphasizing patience and gradual progress.
First Example Sentence: Keep saving likkle by likkle—one one coco full di basket.
Second Example Sentence: Mi nuh rich yet, but mi a try—one one coco full di basket.
Third Example Sentence: Teacher always tell wi fi study steady—one one coco full di basket.

Idiom (Limonese Creole): Empty barrel mek di most noise
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: People with little knowledge or substance tend to talk the most.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Loud people often have little to say.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Old Caribbean proverb reflecting social critique in plantation society.
First Example Sentence: Mi tired a him talk so much—empty barrel mek di most noise.
Second Example Sentence: Dem chat every minute but do nutten—empty barrel mek di most noise.
Third Example Sentence: Yu know di type—empty barrel mek di most noise all di time.

Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Reflects agrarian Caribbean life where rain is unpredictable, symbolizing sudden hardship.
First Example Sentence: Yu haffi careful pon di road—trouble nuh set like rain.
Second Example Sentence: Dem neva expect di fire—trouble nuh set like rain.
Third Example Sentence: Mi granny always warn mi—trouble nuh set like rain.

Idiom (Limonese Creole): When crab walk, him tink di groun crooked
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: People often blame others for their own faults.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: People project their mistakes onto others.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from coastal fishing communities observing crab movement; moral allegory.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Limonese Cr: /wɛn krab wak, ɪm tɪŋk di grʌn krʊkɪd/
First Example Sentence: She blame mi fi late, but when crab walk, him tink di groun crooked.
Second Example Sentence: Dem point finger quick—when crab walk, him tink di groun crooked.
Third Example Sentence: Mi laugh cause it true—when crab walk, him tink di groun crooked.

Idiom (Limonese Creole): Cow neva know di use a him tail till fly tek him
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: People don’t value what they have until it’s gone or needed.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: You don’t appreciate something until you lose it.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Agricultural imagery common in Caribbean proverbs, especially among farmers.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Limonese Cr: /kaʊ ˈnevʌ noʊ di jus a ɪm teɪl tɪl flaɪ tɛk ɪm/
First Example Sentence: Mi miss mi old car now—cow neva know di use a him tail till fly tek him.
Second Example Sentence: She cry when him lef—cow neva know di use a him tail till fly tek him.
Third Example Sentence: Yu only see value when it gone—cow neva know di use a him tail till fly tek him.

Idiom (Limonese Creole): If yu want good, yu nose haffi run
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To achieve success, you must make sacrifices or endure hardship.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rooted in folk wisdom emphasizing perseverance through discomfort.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Limonese Cr: /ɪf ju want ɡʊd, ju noʊz hafi rʌn/
First Example Sentence: Yu cyaan quit now—if yu want good, yu nose haffi run.
Second Example Sentence: Dem haffi train hard—if yu want good, yu nose haffi run.
Third Example Sentence: Teacher tell wi di same ting—if yu want good, yu nose haffi run.

Idiom (Limonese Creole): Play wid puppy, puppy lick yu mouth
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: If you act too friendly, people may disrespect you.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from rural wisdom about discipline and respect.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Limonese Cr: /pleɪ wɪd ˈpʌpi, ˈpʌpi lɪk ju moʊt/
First Example Sentence: Yu haffi draw di line—play wid puppy, puppy lick yu mouth.
Second Example Sentence: Dem tek liberty cause yu soft—play wid puppy, puppy lick yu mouth.
Third Example Sentence: Boss warn him already—play wid puppy, puppy lick yu mouth.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Every small contribution adds up to something significant.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Small things combine to make something bigger.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Caribbean proverb of British origin adapted in Creole speech.
First Example Sentence: Mi save likkle change every day—every mickle mek a muckle.
Second Example Sentence: Yu effort matter—every mickle mek a muckle.
Third Example Sentence: Mama always say dat—every mickle mek a muckle.

Idiom (Limonese Creole): When di drum beat, fowl mus dance
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: When circumstances demand, one must act or respond accordingly.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: You must act when it's your turn or obligation.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: African diasporic origin tied to drum-based communal rituals.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Limonese Cr: /wɛn di drʌm bit, faʊl mʌs dans/
First Example Sentence: When di drum beat, fowl mus dance—time fi act now.
Second Example Sentence: Him cyaan hide forever—when di drum beat, fowl mus dance.
Third Example Sentence: Life call yu sometimes—when di drum beat, fowl mus dance.
